subject: Relationships
title: Trust Begins in the First Year of Life
description: A quick win: understand Trust Begins in the First Year of Life.

hook.text: A baby cries and someone comes. Or no one comes. In that first year, the brain writes its trust blueprint.

buildup.text: Erik Erikson called it 'basic trust vs. mistrust' â€” the first psychosocial stage, from birth to 18 months.

discovery.text: Consistent caregiving teaches: 'The world is safe enough.' Neglect teaches: 'I can only rely on myself.'

twist.text: This early trust template persists into adulthood. But it's not permanent â€” the right relationships can rewrite it.

climax.text: Your ability to trust was shaped before you could speak. But it doesn't have to be defined by what happened then.

punchline.text: Trust is first learned before words. It can be relearned after them.
